The commissioning process really begins with
a Trustees discussion. So my role as Contemporary

94.text:
Curator is to work with the Director and the
Chief Curator – and indeed the other period

100.text:
curators – and what we do is we put forward
to the Trustees a number of names of people

106.text:

great things in different areas. And the Trustees

112.text:

a discussion about this group and out of that

118.text:

ahead of the other names and they become the

125.text:
subjects of our new commissions. We write
to them and invite them to come in for a meeting

130.text: to discuss the possibly of a portrait commission.

132.text:
We’ll walk them around the Gallery, show
them our commissioned portraits and discuss

come along with very clear ideas of how they

142.text:
see themselves; other times people really
don’t have any sense of that, so it’s

147.text: for us to put forward suggestions and ideas.

150.text:
So then, we invite into the Gallery the sitter
together with the artist. They’re meeting

159.text:
each other usually for the first time, so
this is a very informal conversation to see

164.text:
really if there’s chemistry between them,
because if there isn’t then at that point

169.text:
it doesn’t go any further that that; but
if there is then they exchange numbers and

174.text:

179.text:
When the artist is satisfied with the portrait,
the Director and I then go and see it and

183.text:
agree that it should come into the Gallery
and it’s shown to the other curators, that’s

188.text:
the first stage. And if they approve it then
it goes forward to the next Trustees meeting

194.text:
– we have four Trustees meetings a year
– and ultimately it’s the Trustees’

200.text: decision whether the portrait enters the Collection.

204.text:
We do hope that sitters will come and see
their portrait when it’s completed, but

209.text:
that doesn’t always happen, sometimes they’re
seeing it for the first time on the day of

213.text:
the unveiling, which can be quite a shock to
see themselves hanging on the walls for posterity.
